channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: The State of America's Wallet
item.description: How the cards, cash, debts and assets that we carry stack up.

item.title: The stock market is stumbling because investors suspect a Fed mistake
item.description: Investors fear, but don’t know for sure, if a long-awaited Federal Reserve rate cut has been left too long.

item.title: Are You Ready to Bet on U.S. Elections? A Judge's Ruling Opens the Door
item.description: Prediction-market startup Kalshi prevails in its bid to list political contracts, beating the CFTC.

item.title: ‘Should we let them sink or swim?’: Our daughter and son-in-law spend more than they earn. Should I intervene?
item.description: “She had two rounds of IVF before she had a successful pregnancy. It cost $90,000, which has wiped out most of their savings.”

item.title: Stock Funds Up 14.2% for Year After Snapback August
item.description: The market pulled out a win for the month despite a rough patch. Also: A flashback to the 10th anniversary of the blockbuster Alibaba IPO.

item.title: ‘My husband blew a gasket’: I bought a $20,000 Toyota SUV using financing. My spouse said, ‘Pay it off immediately.’ Did I get a bad deal?
item.description: “I couldn’t get a cashier’s check at the dealer yesterday as I had my four kids with me.”

item.title: Jobs Slowdown Frustrates Investors Who Wanted Certainty on the Fed
item.description: Revisions and other distortions mean monetary policy outlook remains hazier than Wall Street would have liked.

item.title: ‘It’s the story of my life’: Have I missed the boat on 5% CDs? I was too late to invest my $50,000 in the housing market.
item.description: “Where should I invest my money, assuming that I won’t be able to buy a home for several years?”

item.title: The King of Risky Hometown Bonds Is Back
item.description: Former Nuveen executive John Miller begins a second act at First Eagle.

item.title: ‘We’re happily married, mediocre gay men’: We’re 58, earn $160,000 and saved $2.2 million. We grew up poor. Our families treat us like ATMs. Are we OK?
item.description: “Our relatives are very poor, and our acquaintances are either single men getting by paycheck-to-paycheck, very successful professionals or trust-fund...
